content.question: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.A student reacts <math alttext="0.300 gram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.300</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></math> of methyl salicylate (<math alttext="C 8 H 8 O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>8</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>8</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub></math>) with a stoichiometric amount of a strong base. This product is then acidified to produce salicylic acid crystals (<math alttext="H C 7 H 5 O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>7</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub></math>).(a) For every 1 mole of <math alttext="C 8 H 8 O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>8</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>8</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub></math> (molar mass <math alttext="152.15 grams per mole" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>152.15</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g/mol</mtext></math>) reactant used, 1 mole of salicylic acid crystals (<math alttext="H C 7 H 5 O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>7</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub></math>, molar mass <math alttext="138.12 grams per mole" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>138.12</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g/mol</mtext></math>) is produced. Calculate the maximum mass, in grams, of <math alttext="H C 7 H 5 O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>7</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub></math> that could be produced in this reaction.

frqParts.text: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.A student reacts <math alttext="0.300 gram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.300</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></math> of methyl salicylate (<math alttext="C 8 H 8 O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>8</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>8</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub></math>) with a stoichiometric amount of a strong base. This product is then acidified to produce salicylic acid crystals (<math alttext="H C 7 H 5 O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>7</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub></math>).(a) For every 1 mole of <math alttext="C 8 H 8 O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>8</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>8</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub></math> (molar mass <math alttext="152.15 grams per mole" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>152.15</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g/mol</mtext></math>) reactant used, 1 mole of salicylic acid crystals (<math alttext="H C 7 H 5 O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>7</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub></math>, molar mass <math alttext="138.12 grams per mole" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>138.12</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g/mol</mtext></math>) is produced. Calculate the maximum mass, in grams, of <math alttext="H C 7 H 5 O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>7</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub></math> that could be produced in this reaction.

As part of the experimental procedure to purify the <math alttext="H C 7 H 5 O 3" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>7</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub></math> crystals after the reaction is complete, the crystals are filtered from the reaction mixture, rinsed with distilled water, and dried. Some physical properties of <math alttext="H C 7 H 5 O 3" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>7</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub></math> are given in the following table. Properties of Salicylic Acid <math alttext="(H C 7 H 5 O 3)" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>(HC</mtext><mn>7</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub><mtext>)</mtext></math> Melting point <math alttext="159 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mn>159</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></math> Solubility in <math alttext="H 2 O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mn>25</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></math> <math alttext="2.2 grams per liter" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>g/L</mtext></math> Specific heat capacity <math alttext="1.17 joules per gram degree Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.17</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>J/</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>g</mtext><mspace></mspace><mtext>·</mtext><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> Heat of fusion <math alttext="27.1 kilojoules per mole" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>27.1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (b) The student’s experiment results in an <math alttext="87 percent" overflow="scroll"><mn>87</mn><mo>%</mo></math> yield of dry <math alttext="H C 7 H 5 O 3" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>7</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub></math>. The student suggests that some of the <math alttext="H C 7 H 5 O 3" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>7</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub></math> crystals dissolved in the distilled water during the rinsing step. Is the student’s claim consistent with the calculated percent yield value? Justify your answer.

(c) Given the physical properties in the table, calculate the quantity of heat that must be absorbed to increase the temperature of a <math alttext="0.105 gram" overflow="scroll"> <mn>0.105</mn> <mo> </mo> <mspace width="-0.2em"> </mspace> <mtext>g</mtext> </math> sample of dry <math alttext="H C 7 H 5 O 3" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>7</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub></math> (molar mass <math alttext="138.12 grams per mole" overflow="scroll"> <mn>138.12</mn> <mo> </mo> <mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi> <mo>/</mo> <mi>mol</mi> </math>) crystals from <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mn>25</mn><mmultiscripts><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mprescripts></mprescripts><none></none><mo>°</mo></mmultiscripts></math> to the melting point of <math alttext="159 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mn>159</mn><mmultiscripts><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mprescripts></mprescripts><none></none><mo>°</mo></mmultiscripts></math>and melt the crystals completely.

The structures and melting points for methyl salicylate and salicylic acid are shown. (d) The same three types of intermolecular forces (London dispersion forces, dipole-dipole interactions, and hydrogen bonding) exist among molecules of each substance. Explain why the melting point of salicylic acid is higher than that of methyl salicylate. The student titrates <math alttext="20.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"> <mn>20.0</mn> <mo> </mo> <mi>mL</mi> </math> of <math alttext="0.0100 molar H C 7 H 5 O 3, aqueous" overflow="scroll"> <mn>0.0100</mn> <mo> </mo> <mi>M</mi> <mo> </mo> <msub> <mi>HC</mi> <mn>7</mn> </msub> <msub> <mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi> <mn>5</mn> </msub> <msub> <mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi> <mn>3</mn> </msub> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>a</mi> <mi>q</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </math> with <math alttext="0.0200 molar" overflow="scroll"> <mn>0.0200</mn> <mo> </mo> <mi>M</mi> <mo> </mo> </math> <math alttext="N a O H" overflow="scroll"><mi>NaOH</mi></math>, using a probe to monitor the <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mi>pH</mi></math> of the solution. The data are plotted producing the following titration curve.

(e) Using the information in the graph, estimate the <math alttext="p K a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>a</mi></msub></math> of <math alttext="H C 7 H 5 O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>HC</mi><mn>7</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>._______________

(f) When the <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext></math> of the titration mixture is <math alttext="4.00" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4.00</mn></math>, is there a higher concentration of the weak acid, <math alttext="H C 7 H 5 O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>7</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub></math>, or its conjugate base, <math alttext="C 7 H 5 O 3 with a negative 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>7</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msup><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>-</mo></msup></math>, in the flask? Justify your answer.

(g) The student researches benzoic acid (<math alttext="H C 7 H 5 O 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>7</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub></math>) and finds that it has similar properties to salicylic acid (<math alttext="H C 7 H 5 O 3" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>7</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub></math>). The <math alttext="K a" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> for benzoic acid is <math alttext="6.3 times 10 to the negative 5 power" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6.3</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>1</mn><msup><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. Calculate the value of <math alttext="p K a" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>p</mtext><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> for benzoic acid.

(h) The student performs a second titration, this time titrating <math alttext="20.0 milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20.0</mn><mtext> mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of a <math alttext="0.0100 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.0100</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> benzoic acid solution with <math alttext="0.0200 molar N a O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.0200</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi><mtext> N</mtext><mtext>aO</mtext><mtext>H</mtext></math>. Sketch the curve that would result from this titration of benzoic acid on the following graph, which already shows the original curve from the titration of <math alttext="20.0 milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20.0</mn><mtext> mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.0100 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.0100</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> salicylic acid. The initial <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of the benzoic acid solution is <math alttext="3.11" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3.11</mn></math>.

skill.text: 2.D: Make observations or collect data from representations of laboratory setups or results, while attending to precision where appropriate.
